name: MK/Resource_Packs
content:
This page shows you how to make and use a resource pack.
An example can be found here.

Making a resource pack

1. You need to know JSON.

If you already know JSON, continue.

2. Make a JSON file

Make a JSON file with the following text: 
{
  "name":"a resource pack",
  "description":"something",
  "version":"1.0.0",
  "thumbnail":"https://example.com",
  "textures":{},
  "images":{},
  "animated":{},
  "texts":{},
  "settings":{}
}

Replace name with the name of your resource pack. Also change description and thumbnail and version. The other properties are optional. Whenever you change your resource pack, change version so it will automatically redownload.

3. Textures

Textures are for blocks and entities. You can use the /blockInfo command to get texture names of blocks. To replace a texture or create a new one, add the following to the textures object:
  • The property name is the name of the texture
  • The value is the texture encoded which can be done by opening this link
The texture can be any size but it is recommended to be at most 128 × 128.

4. Images

Images are similar to textures. You can look for the images in the code. To replace an image, add the following to the images object:
  • The property name is the name of the image
  • The value is the url which can be a data url

5. Animated textures

To replace an existing animated texture or make an unanimated texture animated, add the following to the animated object:
  • The property name is the name of the texture to animate
  • The value is like this: 
    {
  "time":20,
  "arr":[],
  "interpolate":false
}
    Where:
    • time is the amount of ticks between each frame
    • arr is the list of frames. Each item is a texture name.
    • interpolate is a boolean and is optional
Note: The frames of the animated texture must be the same size.

6. Texts

You can replace certain text like button text.
To replace text, add the following to the images object:
  • The property name can be:
    • The text to replace
    • For block and item names, use 
      block.name
      and replace name with the name of the block or item in camel case.
    • For control names, use 
      control.name
      and replace name with the name of the control in camel case.
  • The value is the text to replace it with

7: Other settings

There are other settings. You can change them in the settings object. An example for the settings object: 
{
  "skyBottom":[1,0,0],
  "skyOrange":[0,1,0],
  "sky":{
    "field":[1,1,0]
  }
}

Last steps

Host the resource pack somewhere and get the url of the json file. You can also host it by uploading it to minekhan.

Using a resource pack

Go to options, then resource packs, then click Add from URL.
Input the url of json file.
After the resource pack appears on the list, click it, then click Done.

Making a language resource pack

Language resource packs are similar to normal resource packs.
Lanuage resource packs look like this:
{
  "name":"language name",
  "texts":{
    //...
  }
}
Lanuage resource packs use the same format for name and texts.
Instead of hosting a language resource pack, the file should be sent so that it will show up in the language list.
